DOC.HEAD: New troops on the way to Panama
Eds: Combines pvs material in a0808 and a0761
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon ordered 2,000 additional Army soldiers airlifted to still-chaotic Panama late Friday, a source said, as President Bush shrugged off a Latin American appeal to end the U.S. intervention and declared the troops would stay ``to do what is necessary.'' ``The decision has been made'' to bolster roughly 24,000 U.S. troops already on the ground trying to quell the resistance being offered by forces loyal to deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, said the Pentagon source, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The movement will be taking place in the near future,'' he added. Renewed resistance in Panama City also prompted the Pentagon to give a new estimate of up to 10 more days for American forces to seize complete control of Panama's capital city. Earlier, Lt. Gen. Tom Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said, ``We are looking to bring more troops in. We are also looking at re-establishing the police force.'' Meanwhile, in an indication the Army was settling in, military officials also convened their first press briefing at the Southern Command in Panama. In Washington, Bush told Congress in a formal notification abiding by the War Powers Act that it was impossible to predict the ``scope and duration'' of the U.S. intervention. He underscored his support for the new government of Guillermo Endara by welcoming Endara's ambassador, Carlos Rodriguez, in the Oval Office. The administration also offered what it said was new evidence of drug dealings by _ including a 110 pound stash of cocaine found near Noriega's private office at a military barracks. Also uncovered at other locations were an arsenal of more than 5,000 weapons, a picture of Adolf Hitler and a bizarre assortment of occult and witchcraft paraphernalia, according to U.S. officials. Noriega himself continued to elude U.S. forces. ``We continue to receive reports ... and the search continues,'' presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said of the deposed general who faces drug-trafficking charges in the United States. The administration dismissed a vote by the Organization of American States deploring the U.S. invasion and calling for an immediate withdrawal. The OAS vote was 20-1, with the United States casting the lone ``no'' vote. Six nations abstained. ``I don't think we're surprised that the OAS would take this position,'' Fitzwater said, adding that the administration thinks ``that eventually the countries of Latin America will recognize and support the new government.'' Privately, he suggested, some Latin American leaders have been more supportive. Bush mentioned the continuing chaos in Panama during a speech on AIDS at the National Institutes of Health, saying: ``We sorrow at the casualties in Panama, but we know nothing is more crucial to peace on earth than freedom and democracy.'' With American troops under fire at Christmastime, Bush told his audience, ``I assure you that through these holidays we will not forget our brave soldiers down there and their families.'' ``We will continue to do what is necessary to help the people of Panama achieve the democratic society that they voted for and that they so rightfully deserve,'' Bush said. After the midday speech, Bush flew by helicopter to the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., where he will remain through Christmas. Aides said that Bush would keep in touch on developments in Panama by phone. On Sunday, Bush will deliver a holiday message to U.S. Armed Forces worldwide over the Armed Forces Radio Network. A week later, on Sunday Dec. 31, he will visit wounded soldiers who have been flown from Panama to Lackland Air Force Base and at Fort Sam Houston, both near San Antonio. Early Friday, Bush formally notified Congress of his reasons for ordering the military assault. While asserting that the worst fighting had ended, Bush told Congress, ``It is not possible at this time to predict the precise scope and duration of the military operations or how long the temporary increase of U.S. forces in Panama will be required.'' Bush's notice to Congress complied with the War Powers Act, which requires formal notification any time U.S. military forces are sent into action. The administration contends the act is unconstitutional, but follows it anyway. In his written message, Bush accused Noriega of directing ``vicious and brutal acts'' against Americans and asserted that the lives and welfare of U.S. citizens had been ``increasingly at risk.'' He also said that Noriega's action had threatened the operation of the Panama Canal, which the United States is under treaty obligation to turn over to Panama in the year 2000. At the Southern Command headquarters in Panama City, Gen. Maxwell Thurman delivered a lengthy denunciation of Noriega, depicting him as a drug trafficker who had a picture Hitler in his closet and pornography in his desk. Thurman said Noriega had been organizing a terrorist force with the possible goal of taking over the Panama Canal.
